m 2 21 44
52
R 3 8 44
Feb 18,'44
Dear Sidney,
I received to day your letter of Jan 4th no. ? Your
ordinary air mail one was much faster and of a much more recent date.
Jan 4th was that last air mail one- which I consider tops.
You sound terribly hard worked. I cant immagine keeping
awake possible for 26 hours.I would be dead, dead sound asleep
with my head on the desk. I do hope it does n't mean flu germs and
spine aches will follow, You must have a h--- of alot of work to do.
I do hope its interesting. Your war out there seems to be going well,
really better than the one in the other theatre. It all takes alot of ti
time, and I cant understand people in Washington being so darn optimistic
and making post war plans. They're nuts!It all boils down to the fact
one should never underestimate the enemy. 
The other night I went out with a Big Shot to the the[a]tre
A ranking tank man, a forw[a]rd fighting guy who has had great publicity.
Charlie Codman took us behind the scenes to meet Jack Hulbert after
the show, and then wehad dinner at my flat. It is always fun to meet
the guys who run the war, and though less attractive than some- we
had a good evening. Last night I danced at Cero's with Raymond, Stacey
-and some local inhabitants and had great fun. To-night I dine with
Alfred Beit and so it goes. It sounds gay but you know what it means.
Just hollow and something to do not to be left alone. I have thought so
much about buying a spanial but think his life would be so tough with
me in the office all day, and no walks in the park- that I have held off.
To-morrow I dine with Ben who seems to be rather weary these
days. He is forever entertaining the fallen nations and staying up with
them too late over glasses of brandy.
My fur coat is a godsend, and dear Rose is an angel the
way she sends me little presents of food and what not. Miss Evans
writes the children are very well endeed and all is running smoothly
down there.
I still take sun ray baths which keeps me from looking
like a worm and I do think it keeps colds to the minimum. Fortunately 
the place is only three dooors from the office and I can pop in there 
twice a week before or sfter lunch for half an hour. 
No golf lately as we are unable now to get caddies, and its
cold anyway.
I had a lovely letter from Miss Charlotte about Anne and
Kathrine and she loves them both so much. She says they are both such
sweet kids and such a great addition to the school. I had sent her a little
silver fox that she seems to love.
I do hope you track that Xmas jewelry down as I have not
received it.
I am busy which is a blessing as otherwise I would have 
so much more time to spend missing you. 
All my love-	Gertrude Legendre
